overview.headline: Daily Education Brief
overview.summary:
Here are the top 10 news articles from the provided list, along with a brief summary of each:

1. **Federal special education staff may get their jobs back. But for how long?** (NPR Topics: Education)
The US Department of Education has reversed layoffs of 465 staff members, but employees fear they won't return to work as usual.

2. **Ed. Dept. Layoffs Are Reversed, But Staff Fear Things Won't Return to Normal** (Education Week)
The US Department of Education has reversed layoffs of 465 staff members, but employees fear they won't return to work as usual.

3. **Did You Follow This Week's Education News? Take This Quiz** (Education Week)
This quiz tests your knowledge of the latest education news and trends.

4. **How Schools Are Navigating AI Advances** (EdWeek)
The Trump administration's executive order calls for training teachers in artificial intelligence, but some educators are skeptical about its impact on teaching.

5. **He Helped Cities Anticipate Damage From Storms** (NYT > Education)
Austin Becker, a climatologist, helped cities anticipate damage from storms by developing early warning systems.

6. **Some schools in England taking up to six times more special needs pupils t

items.title: Councils Warn of 'Total Collapse' in Special Needs System
items.summary: Councils in England are warning of a 'total collapse' in the special educational needs and disabilities system due to increasing demand and deficits. The County Councils Network says councils will face £4.4bn annual deficits by 2029, with demand for support expected to increase.
bullets: The number of Education Health and Care Plans (EHCPs) has increased by 10.8% to 638,745 in January 2025
Demand for EHCPs alone is not the only factor driving spiralling expenditure, with 'over-reliance on higher costs placements and special provision' also a factor

items.title: Did You Follow This Week's Education News? Take This Quiz
items.summary: This quiz tests your knowledge of the latest education news and trends. It covers topics such as leadership, policy, teaching, technology, and more. The quiz is designed to help you stay up-to-date on the latest developments in the field.
bullets: - Test your knowledge on the latest news and trends in education.
- Explore the full stories behind the quiz questions.
- Learn how districts are strengthening MTSS to accelerate literacy growth.

{

  "source": "BBC News",
  "url": "https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c740gvyv74o?at_medium=RSS&at_campaign=rss",

items.title: Ed. Dept. Layoffs Are Reversed, But Staff Fear Things Won't Return to Normal
items.summary: The US Department of Education has reversed layoffs of 465 staff members, but employees fear they won't return to work as usual. Staff have been resistant to reinstatement and worry about the department's ability to carry out key functions.
bullets: Reversed layoffs will not restore offices that oversee key grant programs
Staff were kept on paid administrative leave, with some receiving millions of dollars each week
Employees fear continued uncertainty and threats of further layoffs
